Utterance: Welcome back! It’s great to see you again. How have things been since our last session?
Hi! I’ve been trying out the mindfulness exercise before bed, and I think it’s helping a bit.
That’s fantastic to hear! How has it impacted your sleep or your overall stress levels?
I’ve noticed I fall asleep a little faster, and I feel less anxious about the day ahead.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: That’s a significant improvement! It sounds like you’re making progress. Have you had a chance to start working on your grad school application?
Yes, I’ve started drafting my personal statement. It’s still a work in progress, but I feel good about it.
That’s excellent! What part of the process has felt the most challenging so far?
I think it’s just finding the right words to express my experiences and aspirations. It feels daunting.
It can be tough to articulate our thoughts and feelings. Would you like to brainstorm some ideas together?
Sure, I’d appreciate that.
Let’s start with your motivations for pursuing grad school. Why is this important to you?
Well, I want to deepen my knowledge in physics and contribute to research. I also want to teach at a higher level.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: Those are great motivations! How about sharing a personal story that illustrates your passion for physics?
I could talk about my experience in that physics class in high school.
That sounds like a strong starting point! How did that experience shape your path?
My teacher really inspired me to think critically and explore concepts deeply. It made me realize I wanted to share that passion with others.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That’s a powerful narrative. Incorporating that into your personal statement could resonate well with admission committees. How do you feel about that approach?
I like it! It feels authentic and true to my journey.
Perfect! Remember, authenticity is key. Now, have you considered who you might ask for feedback on your draft?
I was thinking of asking a couple of colleagues who have gone through the process themselves.
That’s a great idea! They can provide valuable insights. Are you feeling more comfortable reaching out to them now?
Yes, I think so. I feel like I have a better grasp on what I want to ask.
That’s wonderful! It’s a sign of growth. How about we role-play that request again, just to reinforce your confidence?
Sure! “Hey, I’m working on my personal statement for grad school, and I’d love your feedback on it when you have time.”
That’s a solid approach! You could also add, “I’m looking for specific insights on how I can improve my narrative.” How does that feel?
That feels even better. It gives them a clearer idea of what I need.
Exactly! You’re doing great. Now, shifting gears again, how has your sleep been since we last spoke?
It’s been pretty good! I’m still using the mindfulness technique, and I think it’s really helping.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: That’s excellent to hear! Have you noticed any changes in your mood or energy levels during the day?
I feel more focused and less irritable. It’s a nice change.
That’s fantastic! It seems like the mindfulness practice is positively affecting your overall well-being. Is there anything else you’d like to explore today?
I think I’m good for now. I feel more equipped to tackle my application and keep working on my sleep.
I’m glad to hear that! Remember, progress takes time, and you’re doing wonderfully. I look forward to hearing how everything goes in our next session.
Thank you! I appreciate your help.
You’re welcome! Take care, and see you next time!
Goodbye!
